sub_topic: Calculation of the ionization energy of atoms
message_1: What is the ionization energy required to remove an electron from the ground state of a hydrogen atom?
message_2:
The ionization energy required to remove an electron from the ground state of a hydrogen atom can be calculated using the Rydberg formula for the energy levels of the hydrogen atom:

E = -13.6 eV * (Z^2 / n^2)

where E is the energy of the electron, Z is the atomic number (Z = 1 for hydrogen), and n is the principal quantum number (n = 1 for the ground state).

E = -13.6 eV * (1^2 / 1^2)
E = -13.6 eV

The ionization energy is the energy required to remove the electron from its current energy level to an infinitely separated state (n = âˆž). Since the energy of the electron in the ground state is -13.6 eV, the ionization energy required to remove the electron is the absolute value of this energy:

Ionization energy = |-13.6 eV| = 13.6 eV
